task_monitor.recovery_strategies module

class task_monitor.recovery_strategies.RecoveryStrategies(tasks_config)[source]

Bases: object

This class is responsible for determining the recovery task to execute when given the request for assistance goal and its corresponding context. The primary workhorse of this class is get_strategy() which takes in a RequestAssistanceGoal, and generates an ExecuteGoal, a RequestAssistanceResult, and a context on how to proceed when the recovery execution is complete.

BELIEF_KEYS = ['ROBOT_AT_DROPOFF', 'ROBOT_AT_PICK_POINT', 'TASK_AT_DROPOFF']
MAX_PENULTIMATE_TASK_ABORTS = 7
MAX_PRIMARY_TASK_ABORTS = 50
static check_contradictory_beliefs(beliefs)[source]

Given a set of beliefs, check if there is any contradiction. Currently only checking the contradiction between task and robot belief about its current location.

Returns:

True if there is a contradiction, False otherwise

static get_last_goal_location(beliefs)[source]

Given a set of beliefs, check the last location that the task says the robot was trying to get to.

static get_number_of_component_aborts(goal_context)[source]

Given the hierarchy of tasks in the goal context, obtain a vector of the number of failures in each part of the component of the hierarchy. The first index maps to the highest level of the hierarcy and the last index maps to the lowest level of the hierarchy.

Parameters:

goal_context (dict) – the goal context

Returns:

  • component_names (list) a list of component names from highest in the task hierarchy to the lowest

  • num_aborts (list) a list of the number of times each component in component_names aborted

Return type:

(tuple)

get_strategy(assistance_goal)[source]

Given an assistance goal, generate an ExecuteGoal that can be used for recovery and the corresponding manner of resumption. By default, we return a None ExecuteGoal and a RequestAssistanceResult.NONE. The former implies that no goal should be executed, the latter that the task should be aborted in the event of a failure.

In addition to task specific recoveries that are defined in the various if-elif-else conditions in this method, there are global recovery behaviours that apply to prevent infinite loops, for example:

  1. If the number of times the penultimate task in the hierarchy has failed is > MAX_PENULTIMATE_TASK_ABORTS, then the recovery is aborted

  2. If the number of times the main task has aborted is > MAX_PRIMARY_TASK_ABORTS, then the recovery is aborted

Parameters:

assistance_goal (task_execution_msgs/RequestAssistanceGoal) – The request for assistance. The context attribute is unpickled

Returns:

  • execute_goal (task_execution_msgs/ExecuteGoal) a task goal to execute if any. If None, assume there is no such goal

  • resume_hint (RequestAssistanceResult.resume_hint) a constant value indicating how execution should proceed

  • resume_context (dict) more fine grained control of the intended resume_hint

Return type:

(tuple)

init()[source]
static set_task_hint_in_context(result_context, task_name, resume_hint)[source]

Given a result context dictionary, mark the desired task name with the desired resume hint

Parameters:

  • result_context (dict) – the result context, possibly created by create_continue_result_context()

  • task_name (str) – the name of the task

  • resume_hint (uint8) – A task_execution_msgs/RequestAssistanceResult resume_hint constant for the task’s resume hint

Returns:

a result context dictionary with the task set to the desired resume_hint. Note: we do not copy, so the incoming arg might also get affected

Return type:

(dict)

Raises:

KeyError – if task_name is not found in the context

Bases: object

Given a request for assistance, and some TBD models, the server uses the logic in this class to decide whether to request help from local or from remote human.
